div.p: Reverend and highly learned, especially gracious, dear sir and good friend, I have now received several letters from you, the last one given in Zurich on the 8th of August, and with it a booklet on Christian doctrine, and since I was at home at that time, I did not fail to immediately respond to you through the young bearer of that letter; however, I was at that time in Mittelstetten, on my late father's estate. Therefore, I kindly ask you not to hold it against me, and I thank you for your honor.

I would like to know how I might reciprocate. For I have also read with pleasure the book you wrote against the Anabaptists. I would also like to repay your news; however, during my stay in Augsburg, it has been very quiet. As you write, there is a strong effort to convene a council; this current pope would gladly make his cousin, the one from Ems, the bishop of Constance (despite the fact that the current one has not yet died).

As for the events, they are not seen as good; for that city is a good pass to come into our land. However, I assume that whatever they intend, God will also have his part in the game. As for a meeting of some princes with the imperial majesty around Vienna, I have heard nothing; although it is said that a new Reichstag is to be proclaimed; what follows, we will soon find out.

You may already know that the Duke of WÃ¼rttemberg is holding a shooting in Stuttgart; much is being discussed about it, and it is said that the Duke of Saxony will soon hold one as well, etc. I hear in these lands that things are going quite well in France; from there I can inform you of the situation, and if you write to me, address your letter to Lyon; make sure to know that if it is opened by the authorities, it will not cause me any disadvantage.
I might stay there for 3 months, unless the circumstances become too difficult. With that, I now commend you to the almighty God.
To the reverend and highly learned Heinrich Bullinger, leader of the church in Zurich, my dear sir and good friend. Zurich.
